## Research

Our interests lie at the interface between theoretical/computational chemistry and biophysics. The current research in the lab is directed towards understanding how biomolecules perform their functions via dynamical motions that are encoded in their three dimensional structures. Ongoing projects include computer simulations of ABC-transporters and development of combined quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical (QM/MM) methods.

ChatGPT said:
Excellent — you’re very close to having the site publish correctly! The error message you got

remote: Permission to pujingzhi/pujingzhi.github.io.git denied to github-actions[bot].
fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/pujingzhi/pujingzhi.github.io/': The requested URL returned error: 403
means the GitHub Action does not have permission to push to your repository’s gh-pages branch.
Let’s fix it step-by-step.

✅ Step-by-step Fix
1. Enable proper permissions in your workflow
You need to explicitly give the GitHub Actions bot permission to write to your repository contents.
In your YAML file, uncomment and include this section at the top:

permissions:
  contents: write
  pages: write
  id-token: write
This must appear at the same level as on: and jobs: — like this:

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

name: Render and Publish

permissions:
  contents: write
  pages: write
  id-token: write
2. Use the built-in GitHub token, not your own PAT
You currently have:

env:
  GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.QUARTO_PUB_AUTH_TOKEN }}
Instead, use the built-in ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }} (automatically provided by GitHub Actions, and has repo write access when permissions are set):

env:
  GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
Then you can remove or ignore QUARTO_PUB_AUTH_TOKEN — you don’t need a separate PAT for publishing to your own repo.

3. Ensure Pages is enabled in your repo settings
Go to:
Settings → Pages → Build and deployment

Then ensure:

Source: “Deploy from a branch”

Branch: gh-pages

Folder: / (root)

If gh-pages doesn’t exist yet, it will be created on first successful deploy.

4. (Optional) Clean up existing branch protection rules
If you have a branch protection rule on gh-pages that disallows pushes, it will also cause a 403 error.
Go to:
Settings → Branches → Branch protection rules, and if you have one for gh-pages, either:

Uncheck “Restrict who can push to matching branches,” or

Allow “GitHub Actions” to bypass the rule.

5. Final minimal working example
Here’s a cleaned-up working quarto-publish.yml:

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main

name: Render and Publish

permissions:
  contents: write
  pages: write
  id-token: write

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Check out repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Quarto
        uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/setup@v2
        with:
          tinytex: true

      - name: Publish to GitHub Pages (and render)
        uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/publish@v2
        with:
          target: gh-pages
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
After committing these changes to your repo’s main branch, GitHub Actions should re-run automatically.
Once it finishes successfully, you’ll see the built site under:
👉 https://pujingzhi.github.io/

How to fix?
ChatGPT said:
Ah — great observation.
This happens because Pandoc (used by Quarto) automatically renumbers ordered lists (1., 2., 3. …) sequentially in the rendered HTML, regardless of the numbers you manually assign in the source .qmd file.

So when you type:

56. item A
55. item B
54. item C
Pandoc will always render it as:

1. item A  
2. item B  
3. item C
or possibly continue from earlier numbering — but never preserve your “56, 55, 54” sequence.

✅ 3 Easy Ways to Fix It
Option 1: Use <ol reversed> HTML list
Tell Quarto explicitly to render an HTML ordered list in reverse order and preserve your numbering.
Here’s how:

<ol start="56" reversed>
  <li>Training Machine Learning Potentials for Reactive Systems. A Colab Tutorial on Basic Models, Pan, X.; Snyder, R.; ... <em>J. Comput. Chem.</em> 2024, <em>45</em>, 638–647.</li>

  <li>Polyrate 2023: A Computer Program for the Calculation of Chemical Reaction Rates for Polyatomics. ... <em>Comput. Phys. Commun.</em> <strong>2024</strong>, <em>294</em>, 108933.</li>

  <li>Free Energy Profile Decomposition Analysis for QM/MM Simulations of Enzymatic Reactions, ... <em>J. Chem. Theory Comput.</em> <strong>2023</strong>, <em>19</em>, 8234–8244.</li>

  <li>Hybrid Metal–Ligand Interfacial Dipole Engineering of Functional Plasmonic Nanostructures ... <em>ACS Nano</em> <strong>2023</strong>, <em>17</em>, 17499–17515.</li>

  <li>Bridging Semiempirical and Ab Initio QM/MM Potentials by Gaussian Process Regression ... <em>J. Chem. Phys.</em> <strong>2023</strong>, <em>159</em>, 054107.</li>
</ol>
✅ This preserves both your numbering and order, and automatically counts downward (56 → 55 → 54 …).

Option 2: Use unordered list with manual numbers
If you prefer to keep Markdown style but control numbers manually, use an unordered list (-) and prefix your numbers as plain text:

- **56.** Training Machine Learning Potentials for Reactive Systems. A Colab Tutorial on Basic Models, ...
- **55.** Polyrate 2023: A Computer Program for the Calculation of Chemical Reaction Rates ...
- **54.** Free Energy Profile Decomposition Analysis for QM/MM Simulations of Enzymatic Reactions, ...
- **53.** Hybrid Metal-Ligand Interfacial Dipole Engineering ...
- **52.** Bridging Semiempirical and Ab Initio QM/MM Potentials ...
✅ Looks visually the same, renders cleanly, and Quarto won’t renumber it.

Option 3: Use CSS to reverse an ordered list
If you really want to use Markdown’s 1., 2., etc., you can keep normal syntax but reverse them visually with a little CSS:

Add to your styles.css:

ol.reversed {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column-reverse;
  counter-reset: item;
}

ol.reversed > li {
  list-style: none;
}

ol.reversed > li::before {
  counter-increment: item -1;
  content: counter(item) ". ";
}
Then in your .qmd:

::: {.reversed}
1. Item 56
2. Item 55
3. Item 54
:::
✅ More advanced, but keeps Markdown structure.

💡 Recommended for academic CVs/publications:
Use Option 2 (unordered list) — it’s simple, works in all output formats (HTML/PDF/Word), and avoids any weird interaction with Pandoc numbering.

## Background
---
- Associate Professor, Indiana University Indianapolis (2017--present)
- Assistant Professor, Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (2010--2017)
- Postdoc, Harvard University (2005--2010)
- Postdoc, University of Minnesota (2004--2005)
- Ph.D., University of Minnesota, Theoretical and Computational Chemistry (2004)
- B.Sc., Peking University, Chemistry (1999)

## Research
---
Our interests lie at the interface between theoretical/computational chemistry and biophysics. The current research in the lab is directed towards understanding how biomolecules perform their functions via dynamical motions that are encoded in their three dimensional structures. Ongoing projects include computer simulations of ABC-transporters and development of combined quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical (QM/MM) methods.

Excellent — this is a very common Quarto YAML parsing issue.
The problem is not with your markdown itself but with YAML parsing at the top of the file.

Let’s go carefully through what’s happening and how to fix it.

🔍 The error message explained
ERROR: YAMLException: tag suffix cannot contain flow indicator characters (3:37)
2 | ##### Jingzhi Pu (PI) #####
3 | ![](files/jpu.JPG){fig-align="left"}
-----------------------------------------^
This means that Quarto’s YAML parser (which reads everything between the top --- lines) thinks your YAML front matter extends farther than it should — so it’s trying to interpret your markdown body (line 3 with ![](...)) as YAML, which of course fails.

That happens when:

You have an unclosed YAML block (missing closing ---),

Or your YAML block has an indentation or syntax issue, so Quarto never recognizes the end of YAML metadata.

✅ The root cause in your case
Your YAML block ends with:

about:
  id: heading
  template: solana
  image: files/jpu_photo.png
  image-shape: round
  image-width: 215px
---
Notice you have HTML comments (<!-- ... -->) inside the YAML front matter above this part.
That is invalid YAML — comments inside YAML must begin with #, not <!-- ... -->.

So Quarto never finds the real end of the YAML block, and it keeps parsing your markdown content (##### Jingzhi Pu...) as part of the YAML, which triggers the tag suffix cannot contain flow indicator characters error.

🧩 Two ways to fix it
Option 1 (recommended): remove HTML comments from YAML
Change this part of your YAML header:

description: |
  <!-- [Theoretical and Computational Chemistry Lab](https://pujingzhi.github.io/)<br> -->
  Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology<br>
  Indiana University Indianapolis<br>
  402 N. Blackford St., LD 326<br>
  Indianapolis, IN, USA
  
  <!-- [[Google Map](https://maps.app.goo.gl/gsY6GJxhxzBsWk1H7)] &ensp; [[jpu@iu.edu](mailto:jpu@iu.edu)] &ensp; [[CV](./files/JPu-CV.pdf)] &ensp; [[GitHub](https://github.com/pujingzhi)] &ensp; [[Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=RlYang0AAAAJ&hl=en)] -->
to use YAML-safe comments:

  Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology<br>
  Indiana University Indianapolis<br>
  402 N. Blackford St., LD 326<br>
  Indianapolis, IN, USA
  
  # [[Google Map](https://maps.app.goo.gl/gsY6GJxhxzBsWk1H7)] &ensp; [[jpu@iu.edu](mailto:jpu@iu.edu)] &ensp; [[CV](./files/JPu-CV.pdf)] &ensp; [[GitHub](https://github.com/pujingzhi)] &ensp; [[Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=RlYang0AAAAJ&hl=en)]
If you want to hide these lines from display, you can also remove them from YAML entirely and add them below the front matter, in normal Markdown.

Option 2: move the HTML comments below YAML

✅ This is the cleanest and safest fix.
It keeps your YAML valid, your site renders properly, and the HTML comments remain available for reference.

⚙️ Summary of fix
HTML comments (<!-- ... -->) are not valid inside YAML

Move them below the closing --- line

Or replace them with YAML comments (# ...)

Once you fix that, commit and push again — your GitHub Action will succeed, and the site should render normally.

Absolutely ✅ — Quarto lets you add a banner image (hero image) at the top of a page using the banner or page-layout metadata options, depending on your template (e.g., solana, default, or trestles).

Below are three clean ways to add a banner figure at the top of your .qmd page, from simplest to most customizable.

🟩 Option 1: Built-in Quarto banner
Add this to your YAML front matter (before the closing ---):

---
title: "Jingzhi Pu"
subtitle: "Associate Professor"

  Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology<br>
  Indiana University Indianapolis<br>
  402 N. Blackford St., LD 326<br>
  Indianapolis, IN, USA

navbar: false
banner: 
  image: files/banner.jpg   # path to your banner image
  position: center          # or top, bottom, left, right
  style: "height: 250px; object-fit: cover;"  # adjust height as you like
about:
  id: heading
  template: solana
  image: files/jpu_photo.png
  image-shape: round
  image-width: 215px
---
✅ Effect:
A full-width banner appears above your page title, spanning the top.
It automatically adapts to dark/light mode and resizes for mobile.

🟨 Option 2: Manually insert banner in Markdown body
If your template doesn’t support the banner: key (some minimal templates don’t), you can add the banner manually just below the YAML front matter:

---

subtitle: "Associate Professor"
description: |
  Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology<br>
  Indiana University Indianapolis<br>
  402 N. Blackford St., LD 326<br>

---

<div style="width: 100%; text-align: center;">
  <img src="files/banner.jpg" alt="Banner" style="width:100%; max-height:250px; object-fit:cover; border-radius:0;">
</div>
✅ Effect:
This works for all templates. It gives you full control over how the banner appears (height, borders, alignment).

🟦 Option 3: Site-wide banner (if you want it on every page)
If this .qmd is part of a Quarto website, you can define a global banner in _quarto.yml so all pages share it:

website:
  title: "Jingzhi Pu"
  navbar:
    background: primary
  page-footer:
    left: "© 2025 Jingzhi Pu"
    right: "[GitHub](https://github.com/pujingzhi)"
  banner:
    image: files/banner.jpg
    style: "height: 250px; object-fit: cover;"
✅ Effect:
Same banner automatically appears at the top of every rendered page.

🧭 Tips
Keep banner width = your site width (typically 100%).

Use .jpg or .png files placed in files/ or images/ folder.

For sharpness on Retina displays, make your banner at least 2000 px wide.

Use object-fit: cover to ensure it scales nicely without stretching.
